ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Dictations, harmonic analysis

We focused on honing our skills in reading and performing rhythms and melodies. We learned how to identify and name the chords within the context of a chord progression in a song, and in particular when these chords were the standard triads in a major or minor scale. We practiced the movable-do solfege system and the ability to translate to and from this system quickly.
I learned about sight singing and different types of musical dictations.
Ability to rely less on perfect pitch?
Dictation was a focus of the course and I definitely developed new skills that helped me with that. Learning roman numeral analysis was also extremely helpful.
I learned a great deal about ear training and aural theory.
Dictation and solfge and sight-singing abilities.
Eat training, chord recognition, sight singing
I greatly improved my ability to sight read and sing this semester. Overall, my musicianship improved tremendously and I feel every aspect of this course was applicable to my musical skill.
I developed basic theory skills both written and aurally.
This course provided a good place for learning more about music theory
Reading and singing intervals, sight singing, rhythmic + melodic dictation, identifying chord progressions

My dictation skills really saw a lot of improvement by the end of this course through the many different exercises and bits of theory that was taught to me. The chordal progressions and basic structures of melodies such as the 1-1-2 figures were really integrated into my mind and my approach to both music outside of this class and music that the class analyzes has improved and deepened. I think my singing skills and harmonization has also improved.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Class is great; low stress, but we learn a lot. It helps a lot with ear training.

Overall, this course was excellent. The main difficulty for me was the two-part rhythm sight-reading that we often did during classes. I felt as though there was a significant jump in difficulty from the (relatively easy) single-part rhythms we covered earlier, to the two-part rhythms. However, this could also be a reflection of my need to go home and practice more of these rhythms, so it's perhaps not an issue with the course.

The course covers a lot of material and the material can be quite difficult, depending on your musical background. It might be a good idea to offer an intermediary course that covers the content a bit slower for less advanced musicians.

Very chill. Not sure how much I learned apart from the knowledge I came in with though. This is a class half filled with YSO and Yale Glee Club people (aka half the class have perfect pitch). But the instructor understands that everyone come in with different musical backgrounds.

It's hard to know how well one is doing in the course because of lack of feedback. Also, because my brain never truly adjusted from scale degrees to solfege I don't feel like my sight reading improved much.
More office hours would be helpful
Strengths were how the course was structured, including both its flexibility and repetition when it comes to difficult practice listening sets.
I enjoyed the laid-back structure of this course because it allowed me to learn at my own pace.
In the beginning of the course this course felt fitting for someone with rudimentary skills in music as the concepts were explained thoroughly but as the semester progressed I felt that

The lecture style and intimate setting made this course a lot of fun to look forward to, and the discussion sections integrated the material learned in my head much better. I think that really writing down our dictations were a major plus, but I think that the course could enforce the solfegge syllables much more as I was looking forward to getting my solfegge up to a high point.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, especially if you want to improve ear training.
I would recommend this course to other students. It's accessible to any students, music majors and non-music majors.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Professor Adam is so funny and engaging and it is a very low-stress music theory class.
Would not recommend for classically trained musicians. But you will probably learn a lot if you come in with less strong musical backgrounds.

I would recommend this course to any student with a solid knowledge of basic music theory and who can sing on pitch, especially if you're familiar with solfege. Your sight reading will improve a bit but you'll improve a lot in dictation and knowledge of chord progressions.
Yes.  But be sure to work hard and know what is going on from the beginning.
Yes! Nate is a great teacher

Absolutely! If you are someone who has experience reading sheet music but never with intensive music theory, this is the course for you! It is definitely a little challenging, but doesnt feel completely over your head. I came out of this course a much better musician and improved music listener.
Yes, it teaches important skills for instrumental and all other types of music.

It depends, there is way more music theory knowledge needed to do well in the class than the prereqs/syllabus suggest. Also, there wasn't much exploration into the "vocal improvisation" aspect of the course, which was surprising as I thought that was one of the main points in the class; it was mostly just an advanced ear training, sight-reading, and music theory class.

Yes, but make sure that you meet the prerequisites and some or you may find yourself having a higher workload than expected. The professor and teaching assistant are able to help with clarifying difficult concepts or how to practice them.
I would definitely recommend this course to a student that is experienced in some way with music and has a basic background in classical or jazz music theory.

extras.title: MUSI 218 01 - Aural Skills for Tonal Music
